References:[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH#cite_note-lvmh-fy24-7) | LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE **LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE**[\[a\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH#cite_note-8) is a French multinational [holding company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holding_company "Holding company") and [conglomerate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conglomerate_(company) "Conglomerate (company)")[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH#cite_note-9)[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH#cite_note-10)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH#cite_note-11)[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH#cite_note-12) that specializes in [luxury goods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luxury_goods "Luxury goods") and has its headquarters in Paris.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH#cite_note-Greffe_du_tribunal-13) The company was formed in 1987 through the [merger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions "Mergers and acquisitions") of fashion house [Louis Vuitton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Vuitton "Louis Vuitton") (founded in 1854) with Moët Hennessy, which had been established by the 1971 merger between the [champagne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Champagne "Champagne") producer [Moët & Chandon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo%C3%ABt_%26_Chandon "Moët & Chandon") (founded in 1743) and the [cognac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognac "Cognac") producer [Hennessy](http ### SOURCE 3 URL: https://www.weforum.org/organizations/lvmh-moet-hennessy-louis-vuitton/ [About us](https://www.weforum.org/about/world-economic-forum/) [Centres](https://www.weforum.org/centres) [Publications](https://www.weforum.org/publications) [Events](https://www.weforum.org/events) [Forum Stories](https://www.weforum.org/stories) [Intelligence](https://intelligence.weforum.org/) Sorry we couldn't load the data. Please, try again later [My forum link](https://my.weforum.org/home) [User profile link](https://my.weforum.org/network/people//) HeadquartersFrance # LVMH Moët Hennessy - Louis Vuitton LVMH Moët Hennessy - Louis Vuitton is a luxury goods group active in five segments: fashion and leather goods, perfumes and cosmetics, watches and jewellery, wines and spirits, and selective retailing. It has over 65 brands, including Louis Vuitton, Fendi, Guerlain, Givenchy, Parfums Christian Dior, Bulgari, TAG Heuer, Chaumet, Moët & Chandon, Dom Pérignon, Château d'Yquem, Le Bon Marché, Sephora and DFS. [Visit the LVMH Moët Hennessy - Louis Vuitton website \\ ![](https://www.weforum.org/assets/link-arrow-white-83f4d7c0d49750ad8e45fade6b2f6877e192c3ca740440b34fbdef3e546561e5.svg)](http://www.lvmh.com/) EN [ES](https://es.weforum.org/organizations/lvmh-moet-hennessy-louis-vuitton/) [中文](https://cn.weforum.org/organizations/lvmh-moet-hennessy-louis-vuitton/) [日本語](https://jp.weforum.org/organizations/lvmh-moet-hennessy-louis-vuitton/) Remove menu ### SOURCE 4 URL: https://www.vogue.com/article/the-vogue-business-funding-tracker [Skip to main content](https://www.vogue.com/article/the-vogue-business-funding-tracker#main-content) Save StorySave this story Save StorySave this story Introducing the _Vogue Business_ Funding Tracker, a running list highlighting the most notable and intriguing investment and M&A activity in fashion and beauty. From emerging disruptors to legacy giants undergoing major changes, we spotlight the deals that are shifting the dynamics of the sectors we cover, including fashion, beauty, tech and sustainability. ## **February 2026** **Fred Segal** **Company description**: Founded in 1961, Fred Segal is known for its Californian aesthetic and Melrose Avenue flagship boutique, which has been referenced in pop culture by _Beverly Hills, 90210_, _Clueless_ and more. Canada-based womenswear brand Aritzia has acquired Fred Segal for an undisclosed sum. **Funding and round**: Acquisition, terms undisclosed. **Investor(s)**: Aritzia. **Investor comments**: “Fred Segal has long been a cultural touchstone in Los Angeles — a place where creativity, community, and style converge,” said Jennifer Wong, CEO of Aritzia. “We are honored to steward and evolve this iconic brand for a new generation, with the elevated experience and everyday luxury that define Aritzia.” **Project Lobster** **Company description**: Project Lobster is a Spanish eyewear brand known for its accessibly priced modern designs. The brand has been acquired by Amsterdam-based eyewear brand Ace & Tate, in a bid for the latter to expand its footprint in Spain. **Funding and round**: Acquisition, terms undisclosed. **Investor(s)**: Ace & Tate. **Investor comments**: “Spain is an important next step in our European growth,” says Ace & Tate CEO Lex van de Vliet. “This acquisition adds strong local teams and well-performing stores, aligned with our approach to thoughtful design and expert eyecare.” ![The Vogue Business Funding Tracker](https://assets.vogue.com/photos/6995fd34f09076ff74ad4095/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/undefined) **Caruso** **Company description**: Caruso is an Italian menswear manufacturer, which has been owned by Lanvin since 2021. Lanvin had been building up its investment in the company for many years, acquiring a 35% stake in 2013 and becoming a majority shareholder in 2017. Now, Lanvin has sold Caruso to Mondevita, the luxury division of UAE-based Mondevo Group, a company that integrates private wealth management, technology ventures, and luxury investments for global family offices. **Funding and round**: Acquisition, terms undisclosed. **Investor(s)**: Mondevo Group (portfolio includes: Meight, Ittikar). ![The Vogue Business Funding Tracker](https://assets.vogue.com/photos/6995fd2e89218c4c957b5edb/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/undefined) **Sparxell** **Company description**: Cambridge-based startup Sparxell develops plant-based colorant technologies. By transforming cellulose from materials such as wood pulp and agricultural waste into vibrant biodegradable pigments, Sparxell allows brands to dye fabrics without using fossil-based or synthetic chemicals. The company joined LVMH’s La Maison des Startups accelerator program in 2023, having since worked with brands including Louis Vuitton, Dior, and Loewe. It previously received a €1.9 million grant from the European Innovation Council, and plans to use the new Pre-Series A funding to transition from pilot to commercial-scale manufacturing. **Funding and round**: $5 million, Pre-Series A. **Investor(s)**: Swen Capital Partners’s Blue Ocean 2 fund (portfolio includes: NextProtein, Traceless, Avant), Alpha Star Capital, and Cambridge Enterprise. **Investor comments**: “By reinventing color through a bio-based, biodegradable approach, Sparxell offers a tangible response to a major environmental challenge, while enabling global industries to transition toward safer and more sustainable practices,” said Mélanie Le Guen, investment director of Blue Ocean strategy. “We are delighted to accompany them in this next phase of growth.” ![Photo Courtesy of Sparxell](https://assets.vogue.com/photos/6983863718aadf542eb50f8a/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/undefined) Photo: Courtesy of Sparxell **Veradermics** **Company description**: Veradermics is a biopharmaceutical company that develops solutions for aesthetic and dermatological conditions, including hair loss. The company announced its initial public offering of more than 15 million shares of its common stock — at an initial public offering price of $17.00 per share — raising $256 million. **Funding and round**: IPO. **Colorescience** **Company description**: Colorescience is a suncare brand best known for its mineral-based powder sunscreen and SPF makeup. It was founded by beauty entrepreneur Diane Ranger in 2000, and has been acquired by private equity firm Roundtable Healthcare Partners from a group of shareholders led by 1315 Capital. The acquisition will see Colorescience continue to carve out its brand, while capitalizing on current momentum. **Funding and round**: Acquisition, terms undisclosed. **Investor(s)**: Roundtable Healthcare Partners (portfolio includes: Polymedco, Everwell Health). **Investor comments**: “Colorescience has built a compelling platform defined by strong consumer advocacy and a differentiated product portfolio anchored by a commitment to science and innovation,” said Tim Connors, managing partner of Roundtable and chair of the Colorescience board. ## **January 2026** **Lobby PR** **Company description**: Lobby PR is a London-based communications agency founded by Ashley Smith. The agency is joining the newly formed CultureComm Group, founded by Paul Knipe, who launched communications agency Kinc, which is also joining the group. The group aims to “build a connected, culturally fluent group of specialist, founder-led agencies”. Most Popular - [![5 Key Takeaways From London Fashion Week Fall/Winter 2026](https://assets.vogue.com/photos/699c8e0a245b5acc05c3f48d/1:1/w_120%2Ch_120%2Cc_limit/undefined)](https://www.vogue.com/article/5-key-takeaways-from-london-fashion-week-fall-winter-2026#intcid=_vogue-right-rail_39e1d5aa-efdd-418c-a1d2-511323495702_popular4-2) Business [5 Key Takeaways From London Fashion Week Fall/Winter 2026](https://www.vogue.com/article/5-key-takeaways-from-london-fashion-week-fall-winter-2026#intcid=_vogue-right-rail_39e1d5aa-efdd-418c-a1d2-511323495702_popular4-2) By Lucy Maguire - [![Milan Fashion Week Cheat Sheet: Fall/Winter 2026](https://assets.vogue.com/photos/699d891c9b6648d92c98289b/1:1/w_120%2Ch_120%2Cc_limit/undefined)](https://www.vogue.com/article/milan-fashion-week-cheat-sheet-fall-winter-2026#intcid=_vogue-right-rail_39e1d5aa-efdd-418c-a1d2-511323495702_popular4-2) Business [Milan Fashion Week Cheat Sheet: Fall/Winter 2026](https://www.vogue.com/article/milan-fashion-week-cheat-sheet-fall-winter-2026#intcid=_vogue-right-rail_39e1d5aa-efdd-418c-a1d2-511323495702_popular4-2) By Lucy Maguir ### SOURCE 5 URL: https://www.kearney.com/industry/media/article/from-passion-to-profit-unlocking-value-in-sports ![](https://www.kearney.com/documents/20143/0/Kearney-100-Web-Gradient_padded.svg) Search Bar ![](https://www.kearney.com/o/atk-dot-com-theme/images/header/Search-Icon-OFF.svg) ![](https://www.kearney.com/o/atk-dot-com-theme/images/common/Close-OFF-Purple.svg) ![](https://www.kearney.com/documents/291362523/308668781/HR-S-From+passion+to+profit-unlocking+value+in+sports.jpg/fee161cb-3344-de89-8406-fdd794aeef18?t=1750421590000) # From passion to profit: unlocking value in sports [Media](https://www.kearney.com/industry/media)/ Article ![Share Icon](https://www.kearney.com/o/atk-dot-com-theme/images/social/Share-Icon.svg)![Share Icon](https://www.kearney.com/o/atk-dot-com-theme/images/social/Share-Icon-ON.svg) ![](https://www.kearney.com/o/atk-dot-com-theme/images/social/PDF-Icon.svg)![](https://www.kearney.com/o/atk-dot-com-theme/images/social/PDF-Icon-ON.svg) June 20, 2025 As the sports industry becomes big business, only investors and rights holders that adopt and successfully execute value levers stand to generate returns. Press play to listen to this article. 0.5 x1 x1.25 x1.5 x2 x 00:00 [Download](https://www.kearney.com/industry/media/article/from-passion-to-profit-unlocking-value-in-sports) Powered by [Listen2It](https://getlisten2it.com/) In 2025, the value of the global sports market stands at more than $417 billion, having grown at an average annual rate of 5 percent since 2020. Once driven purely by passion and competition to win, the industry has evolved into a dynamic business environment where, like many other industries, value creation and capture are now paramount for most investors in the sports ecosystem. Winning on the pitch or court or in the arena must come with winning financially. As these actors navigate a rapidly changing landscape, the challenge lies in unlocking value while preserving the need for competitive success that defines the industry. This balance has become essential for sustaining long-term success in an increasingly commercialized environment. The path to sustainable success in the sports industry is complex, with revenue shaped by three main value pools—commercializing IP and matchday, gaming, and broadcasting and streaming. Actors seeking to capitalize on these value pools must navigate a range of macro trends, including the shifting preferences of younger fans, regulatory pressures, persistent content piracy, and the commercial opportunities presented by the growth of new sports formats and women’s sports. These trends, among others explored in this paper, highlight the evolving landscape that industry actors must strategically navigate to increase their share of the value pools. In the context of these market changes, investors can increase the value of their organizations through a range of levers. From unlocking latent commercial potential to optimizing operational efficiencies to restructuring their finances and capturing synergies across a portfolio of assets, there are numerous ways to sustainably enhance profitability and returns. Balancing these efforts with the evolving landscape requires a business mindset not always associated with sports. This paper begins by segmenting sports industry revenue into the three main value pools, analyzing their size and trends, connecting the revenue flows between them, and defining the primary drivers of growth. It then examines the rapidly evolving investment landscape and defines five levers that investors and sports organizations can use to create value and drive sustained growth. As commercial interests increasingly shape sports, actors that master value creation and capture will define the industry’s future. # A $600 billion market opportunity Kearney values the global sports market at $417 billion in 2025, with expected growth to about $602 billion by 2030 (see figures 1 and 2). ![Figure 1: The global sports market is valued at about $417 billion in 2025](https://www.kearney.com/documents/291362523/308668781/FG-From-passion-to-profit-unlocking-value-in-sports-1.png/45cf48bc-cbc1-7168-6b6a-4d21eddbae21?t=1750421569000) ![Figure 2 :The global sports market is expected to grow to more than $600 billion by 2030, predominantly driven by increase gaming revenue](https://www.kearney.com/documents/291362523/308668781/FG-From-passion-to-profit-unlocking-value-in-sports-2.png/4dbccd1e-03e0-e44e-e5ce-aaa0114d714d?t=1750421572000) For this paper, the sports market revenue is divided into three value pools: - **Commercializing IP and matchday.** This encompasses revenue from all sport intellectual property (IP) owners such as clubs, franchises, leagues, and associations, as well as stadium revenue when the ownership doesn’t sit with the local team. Non-sports-related stadium revenue is excluded. - **Broadcasting and streaming.** This includes subscription- and advertising-based income generated by free-to-air or pay-TV broadcasters or online over-the-top (OTT) streaming providers. - **Gaming.** This is composed of sports-themed video games, on PCs, consoles, and mobile devices. It also includes online and offline sports gambling and fantasy sports. The sports industry has experienced growth since 2020, demonstrating resilience throughout the pandemic as well as an uncertain economic environment. Moreover, the annual growth rate is projected to increase from 5 percent to 8 percent between 2025 and 2030. What’s more striking is how the composition of market revenue has changed. Revenue from commercializing IP and matchday accounted for the largest share of the market in 2020 but has since been overtaken by gaming, whose share of industry revenue has grown by nearly 50 percent in 10 years, a trend projected to continue. A primary driver behind this is the liberalization of the sports betting market in the United States, as well as a growing appetite for it in Asia, most notably China and India. An additional driver is the growing number of young sports fans who prefer to experience sports through an interactive medium rather than watching passively in a stadium or on a screen. ## Commercializing IP and matchday The total revenue of this value pool is $154 billion in 2025 with an expected 8 percent growth rate over the next five years. There are two main drivers behind this. Firstly, sports has enduring popularity and resilience as a media and entertainment genre in an ever more fractured landscape. In 2024, [75 of the top 100](https://variety.com/2024/tv/news/most-watched-shows-2024-tracker-young-sheldon-super-bowl-olympics-oscars-1236260223/) most watched primetime TV slots in the US were sports. Secondly, sports IP owners are rapidly adopting data and analytics, especially fan-related, to enable more effective commercialization. **Media rights.** This is the largest segment of the value pool, a $61 billion global market in 2025, with approximately 60 percent accounted for by tier 1 rights. The proliferation of services and platforms broadcasting and streaming l ### SOURCE 6 URL: https://www.klover.ai/lvmh-ai-strategy-analysis-dominance-in-luxury-ai/ # LVMH AI Strategy: Analysis of Dominance in Luxury AI - [Dany Kitishian](https://www.klover.ai/author/dany-kitishian/) - [July 15, 2025](https://www.klover.ai/2025/07/15/) Klover built the world’s largest library of AI systems and agents, pioneered Artificial General Decision-Making™ as a scalable alternative to AGI, and pioneered Vibe Coding to architect AI with human intuition. [Get Strategic](https://www.klover.ai/schedule-a-call-enterprise-government/) ![](https://www.klover.ai/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/klover-ai-strategy-worlds-largest-proprietary-library-ai-systems-ai-agents-copyright.png) ## [Klover: The Pioneer of Vibe Coding](https://www.forbes.com/sites/chuckbrooks/2025/08/08/artificial-intelligence-is-transforming-world-of-coding-with-a-new-vibe/) ## Share Post # LVMH AI Strategy: Analysis of Dominance in Luxury AI The report explores how LVMH will dominate in AI.  The report includes the most exhaustive ai strategy analysis complete with references and works cited by Dany Kitishian of [Klover.AI](http://klover.ai/). # LVMH AI Executive Summary LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the global luxury behemoth, navigates a complex economic landscape that underscores the fragility even of resilient brands. The conglomerate reported a 3% organic revenue decline in Q1 2025, reaching €20.3 billion, a significant shift from earlier optimism.1 This downturn was influenced by a confluence of factors, including U.S.-China trade tensions, weakening demand in key markets, and the normalization of post-pandemic tourism trends.1 Despite these macroeconomic headwinds, LVMH’s underlying financial health remains robust, with €84.7 billion in revenue for 2024 and a substantial €10.7 billion in free cash flow.1 Iconic brands such as Louis Vuitton and Dior continue to demonstrate market leadership and resilience.1 In this dynamic environment, artificial intelligence (AI) has emerged not merely as an innovative tool but as a “strategic imperative for sustainable, profitable growth”.5 LVMH’s potential for AI dominance is rooted in its unique ability to integrate advanced AI across its vast, diversified portfolio of more than 75 Maisons.6 This capability is underpinned by a sophisticated, centralized data platform developed in collaboration with Google Cloud 6, substantial strategic investments in pioneering AI startups 11, and a distinctive “quiet tech” philosophy. This approach prioritizes enhancing human-centric luxury experiences rather than overtly replacing them.6 The sheer volume and diversity of proprietary data generated across its extensive brand ecosystem provide an unparalleled competitive advantage, enabling hyper-personalization, comprehensive operational optimization, and robust anti-counterfeiting measures. A notable aspect of LVMH’s approach is the application of AI as a strategic counter-cyclical investment. The recent financial performance, marked by revenue declines and macroeconomic challenges, stands in stark contrast to the conglomerate’s extensive and ongoing AI investments.1 This juxtaposition suggests that LVMH perceives AI not merely as a growth accelerator during favorable conditions but as a crucial mechanism for building resilience and sustaining competitive advantage during economic contractions. It represents a deliberate, long-term commitment aimed at stabilizing performance and protecting margins when consumer spending becomes more cautious. This demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of AI’s utility beyond mere operational efficiency, positioning LVMH to not only weather economic storms but potentially emerge stronger than less technologically agile competitors. Furthermore, LVMH’s “quiet tech” philosophy serves as a significant differentiator in the luxury sector. The company’s consistent emphasis on “seamless data and AI integration for luxury customer experiences” without being “intrusive” 6 highlights a deliberate strategy. The objective is to maintain the intimate, “one-to-one interaction” that clients expect from its Maisons 10, empowering human client advisors with AI-driven insights rather than substituting them.6 This approach directly addresses a core challenge in luxury: how to integrate advanced technology without diluting the exclusivity, intimacy, and craftsmanship that define the sector. The technology operates subtly in the background, making the luxury experience feel more bespoke and effortless, rather than overtly digital. This focus on augmenting human connection with data-driven intelligence cultivates deeper loyalty and trust, which are paramount in the high-touch luxury market, thereby strengthening the brand’s perceived value and exclusivity. This philosophy could very well become a benchmark for AI adoption across the luxury industry, demonstrating how AI can be a powerful enabler of traditional luxury values, rather than a disruptive force. # The Strategic Imperative: Navigating Macroeconomic Headwinds with AI LVMH’s recent financial disclosures reveal a challenging period, with a 3% organic revenue decline in Q1 2025, reaching fundamentals, including $10.7 billion in free cash flow in 2024, provide crucial flexibility for strategic maneuvers.1 In response to these challenges, LVMH is strategically recalibrating its focus Citadel and 4 year non-competes by [Sarah Butcher](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/author/sarahbutcher-en "author profile link") 12 May 2025 5 minute read [Financial\\ \\ **Morning Coffee: Citi's top tree-hugging banker departs as revenues return. Citadel and 4 year non-competes**\\ \\ 12 May 2025 \\ \\ comment icon\\ \\ 0 comments \\ \\ like icon\\ \\ 2 likes](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/banking-revenues-2025 "Morning Coffee: Citi's top tree-hugging banker departs as revenues return. Citadel and 4 year non-competes ")![Morning Coffee: Citi's top tree-hugging banker departs as revenues return. Citadel and 4 year non-competes ](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/img/resize=width:1600,height:947,fit:crop/D0PQyXalTZ6xbJiYqMex) What has become of banking revenues in 2025? After a first quarter in which global investment banking revenues were down 2% year-on-year according to Dealogic, things are suddenly fluffing up again. [Get Morning Coffee](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter) ☕ [in your inbox. Sign up here.](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter) [Bloomberg](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/newsletters/2025-05-09/relief-for-dealmakers-as-big-m-a-ipos-creep-back-in-may?taid=681e1c280e27c40001c7e8b6&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter) notes that year-to-date, M&A revenues are now up 9% year-on-year. This is partly by virtue of $30bn of big deals announced last Monday, including [Parkland's $9bn acquisition by Sunuco,](https://www.parkland.ca/newsroom/news-releases/parkland-corporation-to-be-acquired-by-sunoco-lp) [Skechers' $9bn acquisition by 3G](https://investors.skechers.com/press-releases/detail/665/skechers-agrees-to-be-acquired-by-3g-capital) and the acquisition of Santander's Polish business for [€7bn acquisition by Erste.](https://www.erstegroup.com/en/news-media/press-releases/2025/05/05/erste-spl) Pipelines, which are always full if you ask senior bankers, are now more replete than ever. Giant deals are being pondered - the [Financial Times](https://www.ft.com/content/dd448d2b-4adc-4b1d-8c10-36b840831004) says rivals are running the numbers on an acquisition of BP. IPOs are rousing from the dead - in London, Monzo is [reportedly](https://news.sky.com/story/monzo-lines-up-bankers-to-spearhead-blockbuster-6bn-float-13364877) meeting with Morgan Stanley about a £6bn offering early next year. Brian Hanratty, head of equity capital markets (ECM) at British investment bank Peel Hunt Ltd, is [declaring](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-05-11/london-bankers-scour-market-for-ipo-reboot-after-shein-stalls) that "there are three to five notable IPOs lined up for the coming quarters." And in the US, Bloomberg says paused IPOs like that of eToro are back in play. This all sounds like fine news for senior bankers struggling to [keep their jobs](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/boutique-bank-not-yet-ready-to-jettison-bankers-it-spent-all-that-money-on) amidst the threat of deals being ["deleted."](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/morgan-stanley-deals-deleted) In the immediate term, though, it may be less good news for junior bankers driven to an even [greater frenzy of pitching](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/deutsche-bank-juniors-say-they-re-being-suffocated-by-a-surfeit-of-m-ds), but they too may eventually benefit from higher budgets, bigger bonuses and more hiring. In this potential dawning of a better time, the [FT r](https://www.ft.com/content/09f96152-ca32-4832-8abb-a2c73eed1268) eports that Luigi De Vecchi, one of Citi's top dealmakers in Europe and a man with the ear of Europe's top luxury brands and fashion houses, has decided to move to Evercore instead. There, he will be chair of Evercore's continental European business from July and will open a new office in Milan to help spearhead growth in Europe. Ironically, Citi's investment banking business had a better than average first quarter, with revenues increasing 84% year-on-year. De Vecchi worked on [Prada's $1.4bn acquisition of Versace in April](https://www.pradagroup.com/en/news-media/press-releases-documents/2025/25-04-10-prada-group-versace.html#:~:text=Under%20the%20terms%20of%20the,Capital%20and%20Net%20Financial%20Position.). His past achievements include [LVMH's $16bn purchase of Tiffany in 2019.](https://www.ft.com/content/c7a7b230-0ec2-11ea-a7e6-62bf4f9e548a) De Vecchi's exit comes as ex-JPMorgan banker [Vis Raghavan](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/vis-raghavan-fell-out-with-plenty-of-people-at-jp-morgan-but-he-was-worth-it) is being [paid handsomely](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/vis-raghavan-s-small-salary-and-big-bonus-at-citi-revealed) to run Citi's investment bank, while pushing the business to fund [more private equity deals. De Vecchi's](https://www.wsj.com/finance/banking/the-outsider-trying-to-restore-citi-to-investment-banking-glory-b2802e99) escape to [Evercore](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/evercore-q4) might therefore be read as [another reaction to the new boss](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/as-senior-bankers-quit-citi-a-little-known-rule-is-working-to-their-advantage) or a quest to work for a pure advisory franchise. Or it might simply be that De Vecchi - now aged in his early 60s - wants to work in Italy, where the [taxes are favourable, and](https://www.efinancialcareers.com/news/2021/05/brexit-banking-careers) he's closer to his family and friends. [Vanity Fair](https://www.vanityfair.it/article/luigi-de-vecchi-fondazione-sylva-imaginarium) reported last year that De Vecchi also runs a foundation that's planting tens of thousands of olive trees in Lombardy. "Trees are the basis of our future sustainability," he declared. He can be seen [with a tree here.](https://dimages2.corriereobjects.it/files/main_image_mobile/uploads/2025/02/24/67bc
